newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - April 1.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - New York Times business - April 1.

text.p: The New York Times reported the following business stories Tuesday:
* The Dow Jones industrials, which lost more than 140 points on Thursday, sank 157.11 points to close at 6,583.48.
* The Supreme Court upheld a Federal law requiring cable television systems to carry local broadcast station signals.
* General Electric agreed to buy a stake in Cablevision's Rainbow Programming Holdings inc, which gives it a stake in Madison Square Garden properties.
* The U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation is examining agreements for Columbia/HCA to acquire some hospitals in northeastern Ohio.
* Personal income rose nine-tenths of one percent in February while personal spending rose three-tenths of one percent.
* Bre-X Minerals shares were halted again as many questions surrounding the company's gold find in Indonesia remained unresolved.
* Bermuda-based PartnerRE said it entered a definitive stock purchase agreement with Swiss Re to buy French reinsurer Societe Anonyme Francaise de Reassurances for $950 million.
* Equifax is expected to announce a deal to buy corporate investigative and consulting firm Kroll Associates.
* ITT said it sold its remaining 4.5 million shares in French telecommunications equipment maker Alcatel Alsthom for about $530 million.
* Ashland and USX-Marathon are seen close to a deal to combine their refining and marketing operations.
* Astoria Financial said it would buy Greater New York Savings Bank for $293 million.
* During the first quarter, average mutual fund investing in American stocks posted its worst performance in over two years.
* Market place: The stock market's tumble on Monday was wide and deep, as efforts to push it higher were crushed by sell orders.
* The U.S. Commerce Department issued a preliminary finding alleging Japanese computer makers NEC Corp and Fujitsu Ltd dumped supercomputers on the U.S. market.
* Entrepreneurs are trying to find ways to help corporate customers avoid high-priced airplane tickets associated with last-minute travel.
